yeah so um for anyone that doesn't know the kubernetes slack uh as yeah you say megan i think it's
something around about a hundred thousand people on there and um as of a year and a half two years ago we um
have actually established a much a much more formal kind of process and administration um kind of plan for everything so
within the slack community obviously we have our guidelines we've got the cncf code of conduct we kind of
inherit and then extend with some more um specific to slack sort of
i think it's the communication guidelines you'll find it on the kubernetes community repo but kind of beyond that it's very easy
to have a document it's a bit harder to make sure that people follow it um so catherine who worked
on the enterprise team at google um put together a whole load of new slack automation for
us so we've now got things like the uh report message feature um that
people can use to you know privately uh report any message that they see across the community uh to us as administrators and we make
sure we're globally distributed so someone at all times well at least i think it's at least two or three people at all times
um are there to start it and you know it's fairly informal is mostly volunteer run i don't think any
one of the major contributors specifically dedicates a um you know an individual to
to work on community like slack administration at least um but yeah so we have that there and i
think it's especially important because i mean even in the time that we've been doing it you see
odd messages and kind of well it really does go from you know the odd weird
message or something that's a bit advertising so you know you definitely see a lot of passive aggressive sort of behavior
and things like that and i think it's important that these things are dealt with promptly because otherwise if you come back four
hours later five hours later and um then start responding it already has an effect people see it and it starts to
set the tone for the whole community and i think you know these small things
um they all kind of add up and then when it comes to someone who's just got a bit of a question they don't know what they're doing they don't know how to get
involved it can make people feel really uncomfortable if you know the last time someone asked a question they gotta let
me google that for you link back that just you know tells them read the docs and it's
you know it's it's not constructive to help anyone so yeah thanks james

how about you fast and then james yeah so it's real life so no matter what

i believe nobody should feel that they have to change in order to fit into a career in tech

yeah and i uh i guess my takeaway i think i'd almost split into two um on one side
it's kind of as a as someone who might have more experience in an open source project i think
it's uh very important to make sure that um you're kind of like self-aware and
aware of how the words you say whilst they may be like factually correct or you know technically the best thing to do
you need to be aware of like how you're conveying that and who you're talking to and sort of if if you need to write a big
wall of text explaining like oh no this is wrong because this and the other maybe consider not writing a huge wall of text
and actually communicating with them um to help them understand because they like that contributor may have
gone and copy and pasted a big bit of code and dropped it in and just got it working and that is a useful contribution they're sharing
what they need their requirements their everything like that but you know sometimes it does take a bit of work to
do it and i think that can help really build out and strengthen the community and then on the other side as someone coming along to a new project
it's like i think one of the things for me at least i i think have helped me to communicate with um other
people who have more experience is to go through and actually make very clear where i don't understand things so
um just taking a look at your own pull request and going through and just adding a note saying like i'm actually not sure if this is correct
um and just highlight these areas because it can be very difficult to you know know why something did end out
that way um you know on both sides of that as a maintainer or as a contributor

kind of demonstrating to your like managers and your reporting chain there like
it's not just you wanting to do something fun this is something that is bringing value back to the company and like how you pinpoint
exactly that and kind of sell it because it is almost a sale in some companies especially if you know your company isn't so open
source first can be difficult but i think um you know
almost demonstrating you know if we go off and fork this project or build something internal
then all of these benefits that we're getting from cloud native technology everything that you've kind of built

integrates with i i can people with that manager you know say tecton comes out and supports

the next one and the next one but i do think it's kind of down to your organization the type of work you're
trying to do and then in terms of balance as well how do you keep the balance between them
i think that's also difficult because it can quite quickly lead to kind of burnout and things like that if you're
